title: Indus Valley Civilization Painting - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Module 2: Pottery Art of Harappa & Mohenjodaro

questions.question: When did the Indus Valley culture exist?
options: From about the middle of 3rd millennium BCE to about 1700 BCE
questions.explanation: The earliest known phase of Indian art belongs to the Indus valley culture from about the middle of 3rd millennium BCE to about 1700 BCE.

questions.question: Which are the most important sites of Indus Valley civilization?
questions.explanation: Harappa and Mohenjodaro are the most important sites where we find traces of the Indus civilization.

questions.question: In which century was the Indus Valley civilization discovered?
questions.explanation: The Indus valley culture was brought to light in the 19th CE by the sensational discovery of the great civilization.

questions.question: What type of culture was disclosed at Harappa and Mohenjodaro?
questions.explanation: The culture disclosed at these sites is essentially urban.

questions.question: What advanced features were found in Indus Valley houses?
questions.explanation: Advanced building materials were used for the construction of houses. It included a bathroom, upper storeys, walls etc.

questions.question: What was the primary source of Indus painting?
questions.explanation: Most probably, the only source of Indus painting is the Indus pottery discovered from the ruins of Harappa and Mohenjodaro.

questions.question: For what purposes were Indus potteries largely used?
questions.explanation: Indus pottery was largely used for storage and burial purposes.

questions.question: What have been discovered in burial jars?
options: Food grains, ornaments, and utensils for the service of the departed
questions.explanation: Burial jars containing food grains, ornaments, and utensils for the service of the departed have been discovered.

questions.question: Which animal figures are commonly found painted on Indus potteries?
options: Bulls, tigers, antelopes, snakes, and fishes
questions.explanation: Painted figures of bulls, tigers, antelopes, snakes, and fishes are found commonly on Indus potteries.

questions.question: What colors are Indus pottery described as?
options: Bright and dark red or buff
questions.explanation: The Indus pottery is bright and dark red or buff in colours.

questions.question: What color are the bands painted around Indus pottery surfaces?
questions.explanation: Almost all the potteries are painted with black bands around their surfaces.

questions.question: What quality are the Indus potteries described as having?
questions.explanation: The Indus pottery is sturdy and well-baked.

questions.question: What were the various purposes of pots in the Indus Valley?
questions.explanation: Pots were used for various purposes in the Indus Valley, e.g. cooking, serving, storage and burial.

questions.question: Why are painted figures mostly found in storage and burial potteries?
options: Cooking jars would not be able to sustain the mineral colours
They were made by different artisans
They were made for export only
questions.explanation: Most of the painted figures are found in storage and burial potteries because cooking jars would not be able to sustain the mineral colours.

questions.question: What animal is featured in the 'Pot with Snake Pattern'?
questions.explanation: The entire area of the bowl is encircled by a motif of a snake.

questions.question: How is the snake motif arranged on the serving pot?
options: It coils around the body of the bowl
questions.explanation: The motif coils around the body of the bowl.

questions.question: How were the pots made in the Indus Valley?
options: In a potter's wheel and baked in a fire
questions.explanation: The pots are made in a potter's wheel and baked in a fire.

questions.question: What animals are shown on the 'Pot with Bull and Antelope'?
questions.explanation: This beautiful red jar is decorated with animal forms of a large bull and antelope.

questions.question: What patterns decorate the bull on the Harappan storage jar?
questions.explanation: The large bull is decorated with criss-cross patterns and bands.

questions.question: What do bulls represent in Indus Valley art?
questions.explanation: Bulls are represented as the symbol of power and strength and often are used in art as a motif.

questions.question: Did Indus Valley potters follow their prehistoric ancestors?
options: No, they created completely new styles
Yes, they followed them to stylise animal figure drawings
They did not use animal figures
questions.explanation: The potters of the Indus Valley civilisation followed their prehistoric ancestors to stylise the animal figure drawings.

questions.question: What skill did Indus Valley artists have regarding natural forms?
options: They had a great feel for natural forms and could depict them with marvellous skill
questions.explanation: It is said that the artists of the Indus valley had a great feel for natural forms and could depict them with marvellous skill.

questions.question: What is featured on the 'Pot with painted tiger design'?
options: A long slender body of tiger adjusted between firm circular bands
questions.explanation: The long slender body of the tiger is adjusted between firm lines forming circular bands around the vessel.

questions.question: What pattern covers the tiger's body on the serving pot?
questions.explanation: The body of the tiger bears crisscross lines, almost covering the entire area.

questions.question: What decorative element is shown above the tiger on the pot?
options: Round dots along its entire length
questions.explanation: Round dots above the tiger, along its entire length lends an interesting character to the entire design.

questions.question: Despite abstraction of form, what does the painter retain?
questions.explanation: In spite of the abstraction of the form of the tiger, the painter retains the character of the animal.

questions.question: When were the earliest known geometric designs found?
questions.explanation: The earliest known geometric designs were found in the 3rd millennium BCE.

questions.question: What items show an array of geometric designs?
options: Pots, plates, mugs and cooking vessels
questions.explanation: Pots, plates, mugs and cooking vessels show an array of delightful geometric designs.

questions.question: How are geometric designs sometimes arranged?
options: Adjusted in between animal forms forming interesting patterns
questions.explanation: The geometric designs are sometimes adjusted in between animal forms forming interesting patterns.

questions.question: What geometric shapes are most commonly used in Indus pottery?
questions.explanation: Circles, squares and their variants are most commonly used.

questions.question: What are the base colors of Indus pottery with geometric designs?
options: Buff red with black lines on them
questions.explanation: The base colours are buff red with black lines on them.

questions.question: What is the most popular geometric design used in Indus pottery?
questions.explanation: The designs made in black are largely fish-scale (semi-circular) shaped.

questions.question: Why could circles be easily made on Indus pottery?
options: Circles could be made using rope and stick on soft clay
They were the easiest to paint
questions.explanation: The occurrence of circular patterns can be associated with the fact that circles could be made using rope and stick on soft clay, unlike other shapes, which are very difficult to draw.

questions.question: What understanding do Indus artists imply through geometric patterns?
options: A sophisticated understanding of the principles of geometry
questions.explanation: The Indus artist implies a sophisticated understanding of the principles of geometry.

questions.question: What pottery is from Mehragarh?
options: Service pot with geometric fish motif
questions.explanation: This pot from Mehragarh is wheel-turned, extremely thin and delicate.

questions.question: How is the Mehragarh pot described?
questions.explanation: This vessel was wheel-turned, extremely thin and delicate, made from fine high quality clay.

questions.question: When was the Mehragarh pot painted?
options: With a black outline before firing and afterwards coloured with pigments
questions.explanation: This vessel was painted with a black outline before firing and afterwards coloured with yellow, white and red pigments.

questions.question: What pigment colors were used on the Mehragarh pot after firing?
questions.explanation: After firing, it was coloured with yellow, white and red pigments.

questions.question: What shapes indicate scales on the fish's body in the serving pot?
questions.explanation: The serving pot with the fish pattern is beautifully painted with triangular lines forming lovely pattern to indicate scales on the fish's body.

questions.question: What is the color scheme of the fish motif pot described as?
questions.explanation: The colour scheme is very sober and harmonious.

questions.question: What bird is featured on the storage jar?
questions.explanation: The storage jar features a peacock motif.

questions.question: How are the bird wings designed on the storage jar?
questions.explanation: Delightful bird forms with open-designed wings can be found on storage jars from the Harappan period.

questions.question: Where are the birds adjusted on the storage jar?
questions.explanation: Adjusted between geometric design, the birds look alive.

questions.question: What is special about the black lines on the peacock jar?
options: They are uniformly thick and have a rhythmic flow
questions.explanation: The black lines around the neck and bottom of the jar are uniformly thick and have a rhythmic flow.

questions.question: How many forms did potters of Indus Valley work out?
options: A few forms, each suited to the shape of the pot
questions.explanation: The potters of the Indus Valley civilization worked out a few forms. Each suited the shape of the pot.

questions.question: What did Indus painters develop in their pottery decoration?
questions.explanation: The painter developed the contour, proportion and decoration.

questions.question: What qualities do Indus paintings display?
options: Enormous sensitivity, freedom of expression, love of nature
questions.explanation: They depict enormous sensitivity, freedom of expression, love of nature, natural forms and bold geometric patterns.

questions.question: Are the art forms of the Indus Valley unique?
options: Yes, the art forms are unique
They are similar to all ancient cultures
questions.explanation: The art forms of the Indus Valley are unique.

questions.question: What happened to the motifs of Indus Valley over time?
options: They evolved through the centuries, enriching the language of Indian art
questions.explanation: These motives evolved through the centuries, enriching the language of Indian art.

questions.question: What does Indus painting display about its artistic heritage?
options: Some of the most interesting characters of its rich artistic heritage that existed ages back
questions.explanation: The Indus painting displays some of the most interesting characters of its rich artistic heritage that existed ages back.
